talk.start.para: .- The Treasurer (Mr. Harold Holt) has, I believe, appointed a committee to go into the question of taxation. I want to make a couple of brief suggestions in connexion with that committee. Continually in this Parliament the question of the profits made by companies, both large and small, is considered. Remarks are made about those profits and about the watering of stock and other matters of that description. Suggestions are made that those companies do not pay as much in taxation as should be legitimately collected! from them. 1 suggest that this committee that is being established should consider what is done in Norway. It should consider the question of publishing annually in the report of the Commissioner of Taxation the incomes of all people in this country who receive over £2,000 per year, and the source of their incomes. Then we should see what incomes are derived from personal exertion and what incomes are derived from rents, interest and profits. The Government and the people of this country could then determine whether there should be a considerably higher rate of taxation imposed upon incomes that are unearned, in the sense that they are derived from investments in companies or from interest payments on capital of some description. I believe that incomes from rents, interest and profits should be subjected to a considerably higher rate of taxation than incomes from personal exertion.
- You would discourage investment.

- Investment will continue, irrespective of the amount of profit or interest that accrues, as long as there is profit or interest to accrue and' there is money to invest. Information of that kind is basic to an intelligent determination of the question of the degree to which various groups of people in this country should contribute towards the upkeep of the community. I ask the Treasurer to give favorable consideration to my suggestion.

speech.para: Of course, Mr. Speaker, there is another reason why this should be done. In some of the American States and in some parts of Europe, the incomes of all public people such as members of Parliament and members of city and suburban councils are published annually in the reports of the commissioners of taxation, so that unscrupulous public men cannot do things, under.'the cover of their public positions, that they ought not to do. Also, this is a method of protecting the reputations of public men from unscrupulous people who cast aspersions on their reputations unjustifiably.

talk.start.para: - Like Somerville Smith.

- Yes. That has been occurring here. Just recently I received a communication - it has been disseminated widely - in which that gentleman stated that the Prime Minister of this country had been the recipient of bribes.
- Why should you adopt that sort of fiction on the part of Somerville Smith?

- I shall make my point. Quite a number of members of the community are only too willing to believe derogatory statements that are made about men in public positions. Men in public positions must not only be honest; they must also appear to be honest. They should be so honest that it is obvious to the community that the people who are seeking to undermine the parliamentary institution and the reputation of honorable men-
- Don't point at members of the Country Party.

- When I was speaking of honorable men, I certainly would not point to them. I thought I was pointing to members of the Labour Party. The necessity exists to protect the reputations of men holding parliamentary positions - even members of the Ministry - from the aspersions of a man like Somerville Smith. But statements of the kind that he makes are made also by other people. Those statements are not written and published, as his are written and published, but are whispered from door to door. It is said, for instance, that when a certain individual entered the Parliament he did not have a penny with which to bless himself but after only a few years he was a comparatively wealthy man The inaccuracy of such statements could be shown by the publication in the annual reports of the Commissioner of Taxation of the incomes of all public men and the sources of their incomes. The people of this country are entitled to such information. It should be provided in a democratic community. If, instead of being the custodians of the public welfare, we were employed by a private company, the boss of the company would see to it that the details of our incomes were known to him if he thought that we were spending more than we earned. We would lose our jobs if he did not get that information. What has been done in other parts of the world and what has been proved to be reasonable and intelligent in democracies like America and Norway, should also be done here. I hope that the Treasurer will support my plea.

.- I shall occupy the time of the House for only a couple of minutes. I want to protest with the utmost vigour against what I regard as singularly improper handling of the business of this House. For two and one-half hours this evening this House has debated Government business which I would say, with the greatest respect, in relation to general business, can only be described as footling and of no great consequence. I do not say that it should be regarded as being of no importance, but I object with the utmost fury to the attitude of the Government's representative in the handling of general business to-day.

speech.para: It is well known that a number of members on this side of the House, quite apart from a number of Opposition members, wanted to put a point of view regarding events in South Africa. I say to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell), who is interjecting, that I am entitled to state my own point of view. If he does not agree with it, fair enough. If the Leader of the House (Mr. Harold Holt) does not agree with it, fair enough. But as long as I am in this House I shall say what I have to say, and if I am wrong I shall not ask any person to agree with me. If any person thinks that I am wrong, it is quite competent for him to come to my electorate and to oppose me at the next general election. I object like the very devil to the procedure which was adopted this afternoon.

talk.start.para: - "Devil" is an unparliamentary word.

- If the honorable member for Parkes has a skerrick of seriousness running through him, he will listen to me. When the Treasurer had completed his speech this afternoon, the Government Whip, the honorable member for Capricornia (Mr. Pearce) moved that the question be put. I was thoroughly disgusted and walked out of the chamber. While I was outside I heard that the Treasurer had proposed that the motion for the closure be withdrawn. Then the honorable member for

speech.para: Parkes was heard. The Opposition Whip, the honorable member for Wilmot (Mr. Duthie), then rose in his place and sought the call, but he was gagged. This House is old enough - it should be, at any rate - to tolerate and to understand, or at any rate to listen to a contrary point of view. Are we to have it that orthodoxy, be it from the Government point of view or from the Opposition point of view, is to be expressed by four or five speakers? I believe that neither the Foreign Affairs Committee nor the Cabinet is the repository of everything that is right and proper in foreign affairs.

The Government's action to-day was most unusual when compared with its action in relation to another item of general business which was on the notice-paper of this House for some months. I refer to the notice of motion which I gave last session relating to captive nations. The House may say, "So what?" The public may say, "So what? " The fact remains that for three months that motion lingered on the notice paper and the Government exercised every device available to it-

talk.start.para: - Why did you not exercise your right and vote against the gag? You were weak and walked out.

- If you have something to say, you can say it after I have finished my speech. I will sit down and shut up. That is something that I commend to you. For three months a notice of motion relating to captive nations lingered on the notice paper of this House. With the greatest respect to this House, and to the proponents of the motion which was discussed to-day, I say that the notice of motion which stood in my name was of equal, if not of greater importance, than that which was before us to-day. The position is extraordinary. If the Treasurer or a Minister wants to gag any member of this House during a debate on a matter which cannot be regarded as being flimsy or of second-rate importance, but must be viewed as something which affects the inner character of this Parliament and this nation, the Parliament may as well be looked upon as being the stamping ground of the Executive.

speech.para: If any one disagrees with me that is fair enough; let him do so. Whether my views find disagreement with the Treasurer, with the Leader of the Opposition or with any other person in this House, is of no great interest to me. Before I came to this Parliament I was chasing sheep. Judging by behaviour in this House over the past four years, I would be far more interested and far more satisfied in following the occupation which I had before I came here. At least I would be dealing with something that was far more responsive.

I ask the House to consider very seriously what has happened to-day. For two and one-half hours to-night we discussed something which could have been dealt with in one and one-half hours. Meanwhile, a number of honorable members on both sides of the House have been denied the opportunity to deal with something which is of fundamental importance. There is a distinct contrast in the attitude of the Government, and indeed, of the Parliament, to the two matters. I hope that this sorry business will not be repeated in the future.

talk.start.para: .- I shall detain the House for only a moment or two. I wish to bring to the notice of the Minister for Defence (Mr. Townley), who represents the Minister for Civil Aviation, a position which has existed for some time in relation at drainage at the Essendon aerodrome. During the recent heavy downpour in Melbourne the situation became rather desperate. Very serious flooding occurred at the northern corner of the suburb of Strathmore at that section which runs west of Pascoe Vale railway station, resulting in substantial damage to houses, gardens and the shire council's drainage. Residents in the area have made representations to me, and I know that the Broadmeadows Council is very deeply concerned.

speech.para: I realize that the Department of Civil Aviation may take the view that drainage which covers the natural flow of water from the aerodrome is a matter of no responsibility to it once the waters escape from its land, but the fact remains that the construction of runways and other earth works on the aerodrome may have accentuated the trouble.

Will the Minister contact the Director-General of Civil Aviation, or the engineering section of the department, and arrange for an on-the-site inspection and a con ference on this matter? Naturally, the Broadmeadows Council takes the view that the Department of Civil Aviation is responsible. On the other hand, I assume that the Department of Civil Aviation takes the view that the Broadmeadows Council is responsible. I think that the best way to resolve this problem is to have a conference on the spot between representatives of the two bodies, and I should be very pleased if this could be arranged by the Minister.

talk.start.para: .- I want to say a word on behalf of the Seamen's Union. I believe that the position of this industrial organization has been misrepresented deliberately by Government speakers, and by the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) in particular. In my opinion, the seamen are fully justified in taking any action to have the award which was recently made by Mr. Justice Foster varied. The Minister has retreated into his old argument. Whenever there is industrial turmoil in the Australian trade union movement he attributes it entirely to the activities of Communist officials. What the Minister failed to point out to this House when dealing with this matter was that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has supported the Seamen's^ Union in its request for a review of the award. A ten-minute speech on the motion to adjourn the House gives insufficient time for me to deal with all the unsatisfactory phases of the award, but I think honorable members, particularly Labour members, will be shocked to know that in 1960, when almost every section of our community is crying out for some upward adjustment of payments because of inflated costs, the seamen have actually suffered a reduction in pay in their latest award. Does any one contend that when everybody else is receiving increased payments the seamen should be expected to accept a substantial reduction in pay without protest?

speech.para: In case some Government supporters may think I have exaggerated the position, let me quote from a communication recently received from the Minister. I shall not read the whole of it. The relevant part concerning reduction in the pay of seamen reads -

quote.para: In giving reasons for his award on 24th February of this year, Mr. Justice Foster set out the steps he had taken to meet the situation presented by, the weekend provisions of the old award and concluded that stemming from his approach to the matter " the seamen's actual income for 9 months' work will not, I believe, fall very much, if at all."

speech.para: That was what Mr. Justice Foster said when handing down the new award. He does not believe that the income of seamen will fall greatly in that period, if at all.

Let me give one or two illustrations of what has happened. Under the old award, which was made by the same gentleman in 1955, wages were determined on the basis of an estimated amount per calendar month of £66 2s. 3d. If the seamen worked for eight hours on a watch at sea on a Sunday they received £6 8s. Id. If they worked eight hours on a watch at sea on a Saturday they received £4 4s. 9d. That meant that if they worked the whole week-end - Saturday and Sunday - they received a total of £10 12s. lOd. In addition, if they worked for seven days continuously, involving 56 hours' work - this is at a time when other workers are enjoying a 40-hour week - they were to receive sixteen hours' leave, eight of which were to be in their home port and eight in another port. If the leave was not conceded by the employer and he paid for it, it had to be paid for at the rate of double time for home-port leave and time and a half for out-port leave, making a total of £10 2s. Under the old award a man working for seven days continuously would receive £31 ls. lid., including payment for accrued leave. At first sight that may be regarded as a high wage, but we must keep in mind the fact that when the seaman is at sea for 24 hours in every day, he is on call. In my opinion the seaman should be adequately compensated for the long periods he spends away from home and for other disadvantages of his occupation.

What does the new award provide? Under the new award wages are to be fixed on a different basis. They are now to be determined on a weekly basis. . The seamen will now receive £15 4s. compared with £10 7s. Id. under the old award. But under the new award the man who works seven days continuously, including Saturday and Sunday, will get £24 16s. 6d., which, compared with the amount that he would have received under the old award, represents a reduction of £6 5s. 5d. a week. I think that any reasonable member of this Parliament will concede that the seamen have not received a just award on this occasion and that they are fully justified in protesting and organizing against it.

Let me demonstrate the justification of the seamen's refusal to work at weekends under the new award. As I have said, for working Saturday and Sunday under the old award a seaman received £10 12s. 10d. Under the new award for working on Saturday and Sunday he will receive £2 12s. 6d. Naturally, under those conditions seamen are not inclined to work at weekends, and because some of them were leaving their vessels, taking leave, returning home and refusing to work at weekends under the new award terms and conditions, the court stepped in and imposed a vicious fine of £300 on the union. I have read that the union is determined to fight this matter.

The Government has said that certain people are trying to destroy our arbitration system. If one thing will destroy arbitration in this country it is the practice of the Commonwealth Industrial Court, presided over by a former Liberal senator in this Parliament, continuing to impose savage and severe penalties on trade unions. In my opinion the imposition of fines is not a function of an arbitration authority. If we are to have conciliation and arbitration it must be on a proper basis such as that of the Wages Board system that operates in Victoria. The Victorian Wages Board does not impose penalties on unions. If an award is regarded as a contract between an employer and an organization, a breach of the award should be treated as a breach of contract and dealt with in ordinary civil proceedings. No arbitration court should be able to impose a penalty on a union or to make an order that its members shall return to work under conditions that they regard as objectionable. If the members of a union refuse to return to work under such conditions they should not be held in contempt of court and their union should not be fined.

The Government claims that it wants industrial peace to continue, but its actions seem to indicate that it is spoiling for a head-on collision with the trade union movement. Let me tell the Government that unless it does something to meet this situation it will have to fight not merely one union at a time but the united trade union movement. For some time past the

A.C.T.U. has been seeking the removal of the penal provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Unless the Government takes heed of the growing' unrest among the unions of this country it will have to contend not only with the Seamen's Union but also with the united trade union movement under the leadership of the A.C.T.U. If that happens the Government will not be able to argue as it has done in the past from time to time that the unrest has been caused by one or two Communist officials. In the past the Government has used that device in an endeavour to escape its responsibilities. I have heard Government supporters claim that the Victorian Branch of the Australian Railways Union is a Communist-controlled organization. The important positions in the Victorian Branch of the Australian Railways Union are held by people who are predominantly members of the Australian Labour Party.

talk.start.para: -Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

. - Mr. Speaker, I shall reply briefly to three of the speakers who have spoken in the course of this adjournment debate. I assure the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) that the matter raised by him will be referred to my colleague, the Minister for Civil Aviation (Senator Paltridge). The honorable member for Scullin (Mr. Peters) invited me to refer to the Taxation Committee a suggestion he had made, and he elaborated it. He began by saying he thought it would be desirable to have all incomes over £2,000 a year - I think that was the figure he mentioned - published in the report of the Commissioner of Taxation or some appropriate document; and he went on to say that in any event there should be full publication of incomes received by people in public spheres of life and those on the higher ranges of income. As to the remarks by the honorable member being referred to the Taxation Committee, I am quite happy to have that committee consider what the honorable gentleman has put forward; but I want to make it clear from the outset that his proposal finds no sympathy insofar as my own judgment is concerned.
- Why not?

- In the first place, at a time when the Australian average weekly earning is over £20 per week a proposition that anybody who is receiving £40 per week should be given some publicity would provide the public with a document the size of a telephone directory, and in print of about the same size; and I do not know what work for the Public Service would be involved-
- Make it £5,000.

- The Leader of the Opposition says I should make it £5,000. What is the underlying principle behind this proposition? For my own part I would not care what the figure stated was, because I believe there is a principle important in a British community to be preserved in this instance.
- But your income is published, and so is mine. Why make an exception?

- That may be a fact and I do not complain about it; but we live in an age in which there is a diminishing, area of privacy left to any of us, and so long as I am Treasurer I am not going to subject the people of this country to any further inroads on their privacy than I believe are necessary in the public interest.

speech.para: The honorable member for Morton (Mr. Killen) was critical of the manner in which the business of the House has been conducted. Let me say that insofar as his comment was a criticism of lack of consideration for the position of the private member of Pariament, I instantly repudiate it and say that never in my knowledge of this Parliament have more opportunities been provided for the private member than during the period of government of the present Administration. I say, further, that in this particular sessional period there have been more opportunities than usual for the private member and for motions to be presented by the Opposition or, for that matter, by private members if they choose. I do not think anybody in the House can possibly contest that fact.

Now, let me come to the matter in immediate issue. The honorable gentleman complained about the amount of time allotted to-day to the item which was before us under general business - not under government business - because the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition was a motion put down under general business and was dealt with within the time allotted under the Standing Orders. When we reached that item on the first occasion, the interval having occurred when the item again appeared under general business, there would have been under ordinary circumstances a period until a quarter to one to-day available for debate on that matter; but the Government took the view that although it was a matter of private member's business on the notice paper it was of sufficient importance to deserve a longer debate. We therefore made it known that we were willing to have the debate proceed from the time it would normally begin until 6 p.m. to-day, reserving the remainder of the day for Government business. And after all, the Government is here to conduct its business in the Parliament. Of course it has responsibility to provide opportunities for private members, but it also has a responsibility to deal with Government business.

Now, Sir, the Opposition, acting within its rights, brought forward an adjournment motion which absorbed one and a half hours of the time which the Government had allotted for the debate to which I have referred. It was the Government's intention that that debate should be concluded as nearly as practicable before 6 p.m., in- order that we might resume Government business to-night. It is true that the motion, " That the question be now put", was moved by the Whip after so many speakers had spoken that on our original calculations it appeared the remainder of the time would be necessary to put the procedural stages through before 6 p.m. When it was brought to my notice that some speakers had found it necessary to take the full time available to them under the Standing Orders there was still time for another member to speak and still leave opportunity for the procedural stages to be completed, and I invited the House, by leave, to withdraw the motion, " That the question be now put ", and that gave the honorable member for Parkes (Mr. Haylen) opportunity to speak. I can well understand the chagrin of the honorable gentleman that the closure had the effect of preventing him from making his own contribution, but the Government must remain in charge of the business of the House. It has, I repeat, provided ample opportunity for private members to present their viewpoints and on this occasion it took special action to see that a private member's motion was extended substantially beyond the time allotted under the Standing Orders.

The third matter was raised by the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward). I regret that my colleague the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. McMahon) is not here at this time, but I am in the happy position of being able to convey to the House the full context, if time permits, of a statement which he issued publicly last night fully covering the situation as he saw it. I think that from this statement honorable members will agree that he has covered the position in fitting terms. He said -

quote.para: What has been happening during the last three months in three of our major industries reveals a sickeningly familiar pattern of Communist technique for deliberately creating industrial unrest.

There is no element of novelty in the Communist technique. It is all too simple. It is to seize on some issue which has an industrial flavour about it and use the issue to hide the Communists real design of disorganization and discontent. If somehow or other the Communist special dislike for the penalty provisions of the conciliation and arbitration legislation can be dragged in to further confuse the issue so much the better.
The next step is to seek to involve the appropriate central trade union body, be it the Trades and Labour Council or Australian Council of Trade Unions in order to give respectability to the design.

This has not proved difficult in Melbourne where, as the Leader of the Opposition, Mr. Calwell knows to his cost some people at the Trades Hall seem always ready to support the cause of the Communists.

Another aspect of the Communist technique is to abuse the arbitration system. There is no compunction about going to the arbitration tribunals for an award, to accept the favorable parts of the award and then to pursue by direct action every possible activity to defeat the operation of those provisions which are disliked. [Extension of time granted.]

speech.para: I thank .the House for its courtesy. Since this matter has been raised, I think that the views of my colleague should be fully known. He went on to say -

quote.para: The three current disputes affecting the Victorian railways, the Melbourne waterfront and the seamen are classical illustrations of the application of these Communist techniques.

speech.para: Here, Sir, I make my own interpolation that at least in the case of the Victorian railways and the Melbourne waterside workers, the present leadership was produced by a unity ticket vote which got the results which those behind the ticket desired. The Minister went on -

quote.para: Everybody knows that the three unions concerned are under Communist domination. In the case of the Victorian railways the Communists built on an industrial claim for service grants. The matter went to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and was refused. The tactics that have, amongst other things, deprived Melbourne of Sunday train services were then used. In typical Communist fashion the Railways Union sought the support of the Melbourne Trades Hall Council and through it to involve other unions. The Communists realized that if this was not done they had no chance of holding indefinitely the support of their members. It is now plain to see that large sections of the rank and file of the Railways Union are thoroughly fed up with a situation whose only effect is to reduce considerably the size of their pay envelopes.

As is commonly known, the Waterside Workers Federation and Seamen's Union in Melbourne rushed to give support to the Railways Union. First the federation banned Sunday work, allegedly because of lack of transport, and the Seamen's Union placed a ban on manning of tugs on Sundays in support of the federation's action.

When the Waterside Workers Federation realized that the excuse of lack of transport would not wash, the federation switched, with typical Communist inconsistency, to a plan of its own that the waterside workers should have Sundays off. This of course was in defiance of provisions of an award recently made by Mr. Justice Ashburner of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which gave many new benefits to waterside workers, and despite the fact that waterside workers worked cheerfully and profitably on Sundays elsewhere-

speech.para: As they have continued to do - the Seamen's Union allegedly finds an industrial issue in certain provisions of an award recently made by Mr. Justice Foster. The seamen's leaders want all the privileges and advantages, including control of recruitment, which Mr. Justice Foster's award gives, but have set out to make unworkable those provisions of the award which they don't like.

There has always been a close collaboration between the Waterside Workers Federation and the Seamen's Union and it was to be expected that the seamen would support the waterside workers over this Sunday work dispute and, conversely, that the waterside workers would aim to help the seamen in their dispute. So we find Mr. Healy of the Waterside Workers Federation-
Who, incidentally, has never disguised his Communist affiliations - proposing to back Mr. Elliott of the Seamen's Union-

Who likewise has not sought to concealhis general political views - in the current two days' stoppage. No one doubts the Communist objective - it is destruction of the Australian arbitration system; it is return to anarchy and dislocation cloaked beneath fine assertions that we should substitute collective bargaining for arbitration.
The Australian community believes in arbitration. It believes that where an award is made the rough must be taken with the smooth.
I think that that goes for both sides - for employers and employees alike. The Minister continued -

quote.para: It believes that it is inevitable that any legislation providing for arbitration must contain as do all State and Commonwealth acts, provisions designed to ensure that awards are observed by employers and unions alike. If the Communist leaders of our trade unions and those who so willingly and gullibly do their bidding try once again to fly in the face of public opinion they will soon learn, as they did in their defeats of ten years ago, just how determined is the community, including the great mass of our trade unionists, to reject utterly any un-Australian activity.

speech.para: I think you will agree, Mr. Speaker, that that is an admirable statement by my colleague of the situation as we all see it.

talk.start.para: .- I rise to support the remarks of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward). The honorable member to-night put forward a reasoned case in regard to the Seamen's Union and the unjust treatment that its members have received from the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I do not want to dwell on the rights and wrongs of that case, but I say that we know that this is a government that believes in arbitration. It says, " Let the workers go to arbitration. The Communist Party will create anarchy." Once again, the Government is trying to draw the red herring of communism across the trail. The truth is that the Arbitration Commission has treated the Seamen's Union most unjustly.

speech.para: Only recently, the Government intervened in proceedings before the commission and brought its influence to bear. What did the commission do? It froze the federal basic wage for another twelve months. The honorable member for East Sydney has warned the Government that it must give justice to the workers of this country under the leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Otherwise, there may be some of the so-called anarchy to which the Treasurer (Mr. Harold Holt) has referred.

I wish to refer to figures which indicate how the workers of Australia are sharing in the benefits of increased productivity. The figures were given by the Treasurer on 5th April last in answer to a question on notice by the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns). The answer discloses that back in 1938-39 the wage and salary component of the gross national product was 48.1 per cent. By 1951-52 it had risen to 50.2 per cent. Last year, it dropped to 49.2 per cent., whereas in 1957-58 it had been 49.9 per cent. Therefore, the wage and salary component of the gross national product dropped by .7 per cent, in a year. Yet, this Government persists in saying that wage justice cannot be given to the workers of this country because to do so would create too great a degree of inflation. I believe that the workers of Australia will rise in a body and demand wage justice.

talk.start.para: - Absolute bunkum!
- It is not bunkum at all. The wealth of this nation is not being fairly shared with the workers.

speech.para: After the honorable member for East Sydney brought forward facts which indicated that the Seamen's Union had been unjustly treated by the Arbitration Commission, all that the Treasurer could do was to read a prepared statement to the effect that the Communists were trying to do this and trying to do that. The Government should not blame anybody but itself if there is anarchy, because it has been strangling the workers. It has increased charges of many kinds, and the effect has been to impose indirect taxes. I could continue in this strain and refer to such things as depreciation allowances, undistributed profits, and other matters which are the real causes of the inflation that the Government is not really attempting to control.

I suggest that we should worry, not about what the Communists in this country may do, but about the need to give wage justice to the workers. If there is any fear in the community it is not of the Communists, but of the capitalist system. We have to ensure that wealth is redistributed so that the workers share more equitably in it; otherwise, there may be a great deal of anarchy in the country, and certainly there will be plenty of reason for it. The honorable member for East Sydney has warned the Government. If anarchy occurs, do not trot out the red herring!

talk.start.para: .- I wish to refer to the unfortunate fatal accidents that have occurred at Williamtown, about which I have been asking questions in this House for some time past. In the course of my remarks, I propose to refer to some of the inconsistencies in the statements of the Minister for Air (Mr. Osborne). Yesterday, the Minister was asked a question which referred to defects in the ejection seats or the cockpit canopies of Sabre fighters, from which the unfortunate pilots were obliged to bail out at low altitude and at low speed. In the question .the Minister was asked -

quote.para: Further, is it true that the Royal Australian Air Force knew of these defects as long ago as last February?

speech.para: The R.A.A.F. authorities know, and have known since the first crash on 10th February, that the pilots were being killed before the actual crash. After the investigation of the first accident, when Flight Lieutenant Ross Allen was killed, they knew that the unfortunate pilot was dead before the aircraft crashed. He died as a result of the canopy almost crushing his head. Yet the Minister for Air refused to take any action when I raised the matter in the House and asked for an investigation so that the cause of the accidents could be removed.

As late as yesterday, the Minister was prepared to try to cover up his own inefficiency and not disclose the advice being given to him. He was asked whether the Air Force knew of this defect in the Sabre jets when they were flying at a low level and at a low speed. The Minister's answer to the question was, " Definitely, no ". He said that the question was definitely wrong and that nothing was known of such a defect, yet in a statement issued on 19th April, he indicated that the Air Force was aware of the defect. The third paragraph of the statement declared -

quote.para: Technical experts of the R.A.A.F. have been working since last February to find a solution of the problem of jettisoning the canopy at low levels and at low speeds.

speech.para: When a question was directed to the Minister on this subject, he refused to do anything about it, on the pretext that it would involve the grounding of all aircraft of this type in the Australian Services. In my opinion, the Minister would have done a service to the R.A.A.F. by grounding the aircraft for experimentation, if that would have saved the lives of the last two men who were killed. However, two more men lost their lives before action was taken to rectify so obvious a fault in the Sabres. I condemn the Minister for not having done something about it, and for the inconsistency of his replies to questions in this House.

The Minister was also asked about the types of flights upon which these men were engaged. He said that they were all normal routine flights, but Flight Lieutenant Allen was not on a routine flight; he was carrying out a test flight. The report of the inquest conducted by the coroner into this accident contains the following statement -

quote.para: Wing Commander McNamara said Flight Lieutenant Allen had been an experienced pilot. He had had a high assessment, and because of his experience was responsible for other pilots.
Allen had been testing the aircraft when it crashed.

speech.para: The Minister has shown how little he knows about what is going on. He told this House that he had verbal reports about what had taken place, yet he said that Flight Lieutenant Allen was on a routine flight, whereas in fact, the pilot was carrying out a test flight on an aircraft which had been put together in a most unsatisfactory manner, and which crashed.

The Minister has not told us that there was a near accident last December, when Flight Lieutenant Klaffer was on a routine flight. If the aircraft had been taking off instead of landing when the fault developed, that pilot might have joined the other three men who were killed. No mention was made of that occurrence in the information given to the House by the Minister.

I ask whether the crashes and the near crash were a sequel to the propaganda flight made to Malaya in January last year. The Sabres which made that flight were able to do so only because all other Sabres at Williamtown were stripped of serviceable parts and equipment. Were these accidents the result of what was done on that occasion? The personnel of the base were most dissatisfied and concerned because so many of the aircraft at Williamtown were put out of commission so that the Sabres could make this propaganda flight to Malaya. The information I have is that many of the personnel feel that this is part of the cause of the recent accidents.

The Minister has said in this House that each of the accidents was the result of a mechanical defect, yet in an outburst to the press he said, in effect, " Everything is all right, boys. When these obsolete planes crash, because their engines have had it, we are going to get you out safely. We are going to smash the perspex so that you can get out." The Minister has not told the House what the R.A.A.F. is doing to rectify the real cause of the trouble. When Flight Lieutenant Klaffer almost crashed, a mechanical defect was discovered. Following this incident, all similar parts in other Sabres were replaced because they were defective. The evasive answers that the Minister has given to the House are not good enough. Three men have lost their lives, and a full inquiry should be held. The full facts should be presented to honorable members so that they will know what has happened and what is being done to rectify the obvious faults in the aircraft. We should know whether they are obsolete or whether the engines have had it. We know that engines are changed after so many flying hours, but we want to know what is forcing the pilots to bail out of the aircraft.

The Minister has a responsibility to this Parliament and to the men who have to fly the Sabres. I ask him to have a full investigation of the first accident. I believe the R.A.A.F. investigation committee was not satisfied and that it then called upon the Department of Civil Aviation to assist in the investigation. I believe the Minister will find that that is the position. The authorities were so eager to hush up the last crash that when representatives of the press went to the scene to take photographs, they virtually arrested the photographer and the pressmen. The authorities took them to Williamtown and tried to force the photographer to hand over his camera, so that they could destroy the photographs that had been taken. They tried to crush the story. It is not in the best interests of the Parliament or the community when representatives of the Government try to suppress news and keep it out of the so-called free press.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) brought to the attention of the House details of the award that has been made for seamen employed on ships operating around the Australian coast. The honorable member showed that the award had resulted in a substantial cut in the income of the seamen concerned and that the seamen adopted a traditional and proper attitude, being thoroughly dissatisfied with the position. The situation was that the arbitration authority had cut severely into their income but had refused to cut into the profits of the people who employed them. It was a situation that had been recognized as being one-sided. The Treasurer (Mr. Harold Holt) came into the House and read a prepared statement from the Minister for Labour and National Service - a tendentious and misleading statement in which the Government has again tried to show that everybody who disagrees with arbitration must necessarily be a Communist or Communist led. The assumption always is that arbitration is right; that all the rights of the workers are protected by arbitration. This is a proposition which the trade union movement in Australia will not accept. You do not have to be a Communst or influenced by Communists to take that position. Likewise, the Government assumes that any militant action, any willingness by a worker to stand up for his rights means that that worker must be a Communist or Communist-led. In that case, there are an awful lot of Communists in this country. It will be a very sorry day when the Australian workers are not prepared to stand up for their rights and, when they consider it to be justified, to go on strike. They have not given up their right to strike simply because there is an arbitration system. What was once an arbitration system is no longer an arbitration system. It is a court of industrial discipline. When, as in the case of the Waterside Workers Federation, there is an award of this sort, what else can it be? I shall quote from a communication from the Waterside Workers Federation in relation to a decision by the Commonwealth Arbitration Commission in regard to Sunday work -

quote.para: The second Order sought is in two parts. The first part is, like the first Order, directed towards enforcing, by injunction, a compulsory obligation to work on Sunday under pain of severe penalty. The penalties provided for breaches of Court Orders of this type are £500 for each offence by the Federation, £200 or imprisonment for twelve months in the case of an Officer and, in the case of any other person not an Officer, £50.

speech.para: It is a pretty sorry state of affairs when Australians are put in the position of being compelled to work on Sunday and, if they do not, their union can be fined £500 and the officials of the Union can be fined £200 or sentenced to twelve months' imprisonment. What else is it but a court of industrial discipline when, in this country, which is supposed to have prosperity, a system imposes a liability to twelve months' imprisonment on a trade union leader because members of his union will not work on Sunday. What condition of prosperity is that? I do not know that the Government and its supporters have ever considered that any industrial grievance is legitimate. But let us take them one at a time in respect of the three unions that are supposed to be Communist led. I can say that, in the case of every one of them, if the ordinary rank and file member is not prepared to stand up and fight he is not worth his salt. In many of these cases, the trade union officials who are Communists are quite right. Those who disagree with them are no better, very often, than the scabs and they have no support from the rank and file. Let us take these points one at a time.

The honorable member of East Sydney (Mr. Ward) has shown what has occurred in the case of the Seamen's Union of Australia. There are friends of mine who are members of the Seamen's Union and whose pay has been cut by £4 a week as a result of their award. That is the situation that exists while profits are booming, while the incomes of employers and companies have never been so high, while depreciation allowances ploughed back into industry in order to give a further tax advantage in succeeding years, have increased by £250,000,000 in the last three years. Yet these men, in the industry have to face a cut in their incomes of £3 or £4 a week! Would not anyone with any courage or decency be prepared to stand up and face that situation? What kind of man would he be if he were not prepared to do something about it? What kind of a trade union official would not be prepared to fight for his members in that situation?

Take the issue of the Waterside Workers' Federation. The Victorian railway officials decided not to run trains on Sunday. As a result of that decision, the Waterside Workers' Federation said, after three weeks of trying to get to work without Sunday trains, that they would not work on Sunday unless the trains were run or unless some other transport were provided. For the first week that followed upon that, no effort was made and they desisted from work. Those people were penalized for not working on Sunday. Eventually, the union was penalized for it. Then some buses were put on from two or three points near the centre of Melbourne, but many of the men had to travel 14 or 15 miles to work.

What would members of this House think if they had to travel seven or eight miles to the Essendon aerodrome at 7 o'clock in the morning? Would they go if they were not getting a Commonwealth car? Would they try to hitch-hike that distance? Of course they would not. That was the position in which the members of the Waterside Workers' Federation were put. They said that as soon as trains were returned to the lines they would return to work on Sunday. They said that there was no provision in their award to compel them to work on Sunday, but the Stevedoring Industry Commission is now endeavouring to enforce Sunday work. Sunday work has always been voluntary in that industry. Of course they have a legitimate grievance. Of course it is only a misleading and ten- dentious political method to talk of this as a Communist plot.

Now let me deal with the Victorian Railways, the third of the three cases dealt with by the Treasurer in his second-hand, relayed speech. In the case of the railways, the dispute is over service grants. In every other State instrumentality in Victoria, service grants are paid. Why cannot they be paid in the railways? The union has evidence to show that men have left the railways. It has evidence to show that the railways cannot get the men that it requires. It has evidence that over 30 per cent, of the people employed in the railways are employed on or within a £1 of the basic wage. The Victorian railways have been allowed to become a fifth-rate employer - not providing even the conditions provided by the worst employer in the State of Victoria. It was over that issue that the dispute occurred.

When the railways commissioners refused to carry out their agreement, made outside the Arbitration Commission, to consider these service grants, the Australian Railways Union decided that its members would not work over-time. It decided that it was not fair and proper that its members should have to work six or seven or ten hours overtime a week in order to make a living wage. So they decided that they should not work overtime, although they would do other normal work. So the railways commissioners decided not to run trains on Sunday. The union then offered to ensure that trains would run on Sundays if the commissioners put them on, but, of course, the commissioners were getting back at the public in this way and trying to build up antagonism to the union by cutting the trains off on Sundays. That is why they adhered to the decision not to run the trains on Sundays.

The Minister said, through the Treasurer, that the Communists want the destruction of the arbitration system. There is a great deal wrong with the arbitration system in Australia to-day, and everybody who criticizes it and who wants to alter it is not thereby a Communist. The arbitration system is extremely one-sided. It fixes wages and salaries, but makes no attempt to fix profits. It applies penalty provisions which are costing unions thousands of pounds, but it does not apply those .penalties to employers. It applies a system of wage determination under which, in the face of overwhelming undisputed evidence presented by the A.C.T.U. that wages form a lower proportion of the gross national product and that company profits and the profits of employers have never been greater, it gives a decision that there shall be no increase in the basic wage. A great deal of change must come to the arbitration authority of this country. Do not think that all people who believe that are Communists.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- There has been talk to-night about the seamen's award and the reaction of the Seamens Union of Australia to that award. But it has not been pointed out that the seamen's award was brought down by Mr. Justice Poster, who was assigned to the sea industry when the arbitration legislation was introduced in 1956. Indeed, he had been dealing with that industry before 1956. From 1956 to 1960, there was no criticism. In 1960, a new award was made and what happened? The seamen's union said, " This is a preposterous thing. It is a shocking thing." The union looked at the act, I presume, and found that it had a right to appeal. But did it exercise that right? Certainly not! They did not use it because they wanted a medium for complaint. They wanted a vehicle with which to attack the whole arbitration system. Since then what has happened is this: They have decided on a course of industrial anarchy, and as a result the other provisions of the act have been brought into force, and they have been taken before the Arbitration Court. Having been taken before that court, they then chose to criticize the Arbitration Court to the fullest possible extent. But there was no criticism of the judge who made the award, and there was no recourse to repeal although this was open to them. Instead, they systematically set about bringing Australian shipping to a standstill. Do you know, Mr. Speaker, that the award itself provides that seamen shall have regular stop work meetings, and that it was at one of these regular stop work meetings that they decided on their strike?

speech.para: Is it any wonder they were brought before the court?

The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) says, " Why do we not get rid of the penal system and adopt a system such as the Victorian Wages Board system? " Let us examine that suggestion. The honorable member said that the Vic;torian Wages Board system does not contain any penal provisions. This statement is true, to the extent that there is no penal provision in the Wages Board Act. But it is not true in this respect: The Victorian Government has complete sovereign powers and it can, when a dispute occurs, pass legislation there and then to overcome the dispute. This is not a power that resides in the Commonwealth Parliament. The statement is also untrue to this extent: There exists on the Victorian statute books at the present time an Emergency Service Act. This is designed to meet a situation in which industry and transport are tied up by industrial disputes. Another point that must be taken into account is the very small number of workers in Victoria under the Victorian Wages Board system. The preponderance of workers, by far, are covered by federal awards.

Then there is another matter that should be considered. Look at the current railway strike in Victoria and you will realize 'how the public is at a disadvantage if penal provisions do not exist. The honorable member for East Sydney failed to point out the extraordinary problems that exist in New South Wales. In that State penal clauses were in existence, and the problems associated with them almost brought the Labour Government of New South Wales down. We still do not know whether Mr. Moloney, the Minister for Labour and Industry in New South Wales, is in support of his Government's policy with relation to the penal clauses. On a number of occasions he said, " I will not bring in legislation to abolish penal clauses ". Ultimately he was forced to do so by an organization outside the Parliament. In other words, the Labour Government of New South Wales submitted to dictation by an outside body. If that is the sort of democracy that honorable gentlemen opposite want, then I am surprised that they have the gall to stand up in this chamber and ask for it.

The honorable member for East Sydney said there will come a day - perhaps he was thinking of the revolution - when the Australian Council of Trade Unions will provide the leadership to bring this country into that state of delight that honorable members opposite apparently envisage, when there will be no penal clauses. Does he want a reversion to the position that existed between 1946 and 1949, when industrial disputes brought the Labour Government to its knees and resulted in that government being tossed out? Of course the Labour Party wants to see industrial disputes occurring. It knows how it suffered from them, and it knows that if it can cause industrial disputes this Government may suffer in the same way. But the truth is that there has never been more industrial peace in Australia than there is to-day.

As to the claim concerning A.C.T.U. leadership, it is interesting to note that only two or three years ago the method of election of the interstate executive of the A.CT.U., the ruling body of that organization, was changed, and for one single purpose - to enable more Communists to be elected to that body. As a result of that change, the A.C.T.U. now is very strongly influenced by Communists. I would not go so far as to say that a preponderance of its executive members are Communists, but certainly in a membership of a dozen there are at least four known Communists, and at least another three or four who sail pretty close to the breeze. This has occurred only since the change of the method of election of the interstate executive.

Let us have a look at the position in Victoria. Look at the Trades Hall Council there and consider what it did to a very well-respected unionist from the United States of America, who came here and wished to be heard by the council. He was allowed, as I recall it, five minutes. He came all the way from the United States of America on a mission to make a fraternal visit to brother unionists, and he was allowed five minutes to speak. There was uproar in the Trades Hall Council. He was called a leftist, a rightist, and an anarchist; they called him everything. That man went away convinced that the Trades Hall Council in Victoria was a shocking organization.

Let me make no mistake about this: I believe that the unions in Australia are very fine organizations. The unions fought their battle for the right of their members to combine over a century ago. This right of unionists to combine must be completely preserved, but, at the same time, the interests of the public must be served, and Communist tactics must not be allowed to push aside public interest and leave the people of Australia at the mercy of Communistdominated unions. There can be no doubt that there is to-day a resurgence of attempts by Communists to control unions. We as a Government have provided a number of means whereby unionists can protect themselves. We made provision for secret ballots and for a while this system was very successful. The Communists were thrown out. The union of which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell) himself was a member was once predominantly Communist-led. By means of secret ballots the members of that union were able to get rid of Communists. Now it seems that further legislation will be necessary to protect unionists from intimidation by Communists if they use the provisions of the act. If a unionist puts his name to a request for a court-controlled ballot, I believe that within a short time he will find himself unable to continue at his work, because he will be intimidated by Communists.

It is all very well for honorable members opposite to say, "Ait". That is the limit of their vocabulary. They have demonstrated that when they try to say anything else but " Arr " they simply talk nonsense. They must turn their attention to the question of controlling this upsurge of communism. They must devote their efforts to restoring proper democratic control in unions, control free of intimidation by Communists. If they did this they would be doing a service to the country.

There is only one further point I want to make, and it concerns the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns). The honorable member cannot go unnoticed when he says that every other instrumentality in Victoria has service grants. This is not true. He said that the union concerned produced evidence before the commission. Yes, it did produce evidence before the commission, or, rather, before the Chief Commissioner, Mr. Chambers, a very sound and fine man. He listened to the evidence and decided that the fact that service grants were paid in the tramways could not be used as a precedent to require the payment of service grants in the railways, because the tramways was not such a career service and provided fewer opportunities for promotion, and that the service grant was made to compensate for these disadvantages. He listened to the evidence and made a decision. He is an experienced man in the arbitration field, while the honorable member for Yarra is not. Indeed, I doubt that the honorable member for Yarra knows where the Arbitration Court is. There are some people, of course, who do know where it is, and they are the members of the Seamen's Union. Honorable members should have seen the members of the Seamen's Union demonstrating outside the Arbitration Court a few days ago.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

. - in reply - In a speech earlier in the debate to-night the honorable member for Newcastle (Mr. Jones) made a series of wild charges about the administration and operation of the fighter wing at Williamtown, and about my own responsibilities and my statements following the three tragic accidents at Williamtown in the last few weeks. Amongst other things he charged me with inconsistency and evasion and with attempts to cover up. I deny those charges. I have, in fact, informed the public and the members of this House of the events that took place, in far greater detail than is usual in these circumstances. I am in the position to tell the House that, except for the embroidery of technical detail, the whole facts have been stated.

speech.para: In a public statement last week and in the House yesterday I went in detail through these events and there is no point in going over them again to-night. The honorable member for Newcastle has not dealt with the detailed statements I made at all. As I said earlier, he has made a series of rather wild charges in which he has sought to raise suspicion, without any foundation in fact.

I will illustrate what I mean. He has made a charge that the aircraft at Williamtown were robbed of parts in order to complete other aircraft to make what he calls a propaganda flight to Malaya last year. The flight to Malaya was not a propaganda flight; it was the movement of two fighter squadrons to Malaya to take up their station as part of the strategic reserve and it was a remarkable achievement to fly such a distance without any aircraft being left behind at any stage of the six long hops.

Knowing, as 1 do, the inspection processes of the Air Force, it was quite impossible that what the honorable member suggests should be the case. He said further that Flight Lieutenant Allen, the first of these pilots who met his death in these unhappy accidents, was not engaged, as I said, in a routine exercise, but on a test flight. He seeks to throw suspicion by suggesting that he was testing an aircraft and therefore there must have been something wrong with it. The honorable member does not seem to realize that these aircraft are test flown after every inspection and that some of the inspections occur as frequently as once a week. A test flight is a routine flight but, in point of fact, Flight Lieutenant Allen was engaged, as I said, in a routine exercise. He was exercising what is known as a high frequency direction finding and ground control approach exercise. In simpler terms, he was exercising the techniques of approaching for a landing which are used under conditions of low visibility.

The honorable member has said, further, that I have obstinately refused a full and complete inquiry. As I pointed out, in answer to his questions earlier in this matter, no additional inquiry is called for other than those which are provided by the settled processes of the Air Force. I will tell the honorable member what they are. When there is a serious accident, the first thing that occurs is that the Director of Flying Safety proceeds to the place with the utmost speed. He is a senior officer of the Air Force charged with the responsibility to investigate all these accidents. He makes a preliminary report at once and that is followed up, after the minute scientific examination of wreckage or broken parts has been completed when he makes his final report.

If the accident is a serious one there is also set up a formal court of inquiry under the Air Force Act and if the accident was fatal the coroner holds an inquiry. These processes have been established in a service which, from its nature, is not unaccustomed to dealing with accidents. They are designed to cover all eventualities.

The honorable member for Newcastle has also tried to create an atmosphere of suspicion by saying that the Department of Civil Aviation was called in to assist. I suppose he wants the House to think that this suggests that the Air Force was unable to deal with the matter itself. It is quite usual practice to seek for a scientific or specialist examination of wreckage or parts and if the Department of Civil Aviation could assist, it might well be asked to do so. The Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation, the manufacturer of the engine, is frequently called in on these matters. There is nothing suspicious at all in that the Department of Civil Aviation might have been asked to assist.

The honorable member referred also to some incident of which I have not heard, about photographers not being allowed to photograph the scene of the wreckage. I do not know about that, but I will inquire into it and see if there was anything improper in what was done. But the Air Force is meticulous, I know, in ensuring that there is no interference with evidence by people walking across the scene or doing anything of that sort. Guards are established to protect the area after an accident like this.

I do not object to the examination or criticism of my own conduct or responsibility in these matters, but if the honorable member for Newcastle is seeking to suggest that I have taken this matter lightly or carelessly, I repudiate that suggestion with indignation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

item.para: Is the Colonel, General Staff, Southern Command, the presiding officer of the Army Inquiry into the recent misadventure at the Rip in Victoria and also the officer responsible for training of the type that resulted in this misadventure?
